title: How to Get the Gasoline Smell Out of a Car

steps.title: Locate the odor.
steps.content: Locate the odor. [1] X Expert Source Chad Zani Auto Detailing Expert Expert Interview. 2 October 2019. Sometimes the hardest part is figuring out where the smell is coming from. Often, the culprit is where you've dragged gasoline in on your shoes or where gas has spilled out of a can in the back. Use your nose to sniff out the likely source of the smell.

steps.title: Soak up any gasoline.
steps.content: Soak up any gasoline. If the spill is new, press a cloth on the spill to get up as much gasoline as you can. [2] X Expert Source Chad Zani Auto Detailing Expert Expert Interview. 2 October 2019. It's best to use old rags, as you likely won't want to keep them once you're done. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Let the gasoline evaporate.
steps.content: Let the gasoline evaporate. Once you've soaked up as much as you can, let the sun do the rest. Leave the car open in a sunny spot, so it will dry out the spot and draw the gasoline into the air. Try to leave it open for at least 4 to 5 hours. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Make a cleaning solution.
steps.content: Make a cleaning solution. Create a simple solution of carpet shampoo and water. Use about 3 cups (720 milliliters) of tap water to 1/2 a cup (120 milliliters) of shampoo. Stir it gently until it is well combined. [5] X Research source Another option is mixing together vinegar, baking soda, and water in equal parts. [6] X Research source You can also dissolve a bit of dishwashing soap in water, and apply that instead.

steps.title: Scrub the mixture in.
steps.content: Scrub the mixture in. Using a nylon brush or a rag, apply the mixture to the spill. Scrub it in, applying more solution as you need it. Make sure to use a rag or brush that you don't mind throwing out. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Dab the solution up.
steps.content: Dab the solution up. Once the stain seems to have lifted, dab at the solution with old rags. Make sure you are using different rags in each step. [8] X Expert Source Chad Zani Auto Detailing Expert Expert Interview. 2 October 2019. Get up as much as you can with the rag, then let it air dry in the sun. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Rub in some coffee grounds.
steps.content: Rub in some coffee grounds. Some people have good luck using coffee grounds to eliminate gas smells. All you do is rub grounds into the affected area. After a week or so, vacuum up the coffee, and the smell should be lessened. Some experts recommend trying a short coffee treatment before you shampoo the area.

steps.title: Pour on the baking soda.
steps.content: Pour on the baking soda. Some people cover up the smell by dousing it in dry baking soda. They leave the baking soda on it all the time, switching it out monthly or so by vacuuming up the old and adding a fresh layer. You can also use baby powder instead of baking soda.

steps.title: Add a layer of kitty litter.
steps.content: Add a layer of kitty litter. Another option is kitty litter, which is designed to absorb moisture and smells. Pour it on the spill, and leave it for at least a day before vacuuming it up. You may need to repeat the process several times.

steps.title: Try an odor-eliminating spray.
steps.content: Try an odor-eliminating spray. These sprays are designed for fabrics, so they may make a difference when it comes to a gasoline smell. Spray it on generously, and then allow it to air dry. [10] X Research source Try using an air freshener or odor spray that has antibacterial properties. [11] X Expert Source Chad Zani Auto Detailing Expert Expert Interview. 2 October 2019.
